awd_titl_txt: QGP Strong Coupling Mechanisms and Jet Modification Via Direct Photon-Jet Probes, RHIC-PHENIX vs. LHC-ATLAS
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quark Gluon Plasma discovered at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and now also studied at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), has incredible properties due to its strongly interacting nature.   This award will fund studies of these strong interactions using very high energy versions of X-rays called direct photons, produced in the same collisions, that can penetrate the plasma and can thus provide important information.  These photons can be compared with quarks produced at similar high energies but which should interact more strongly, like the other quark constituents of the plasma.  In the project this will be done through studying correlations between photons and hadrons, which are particles made of quarks.  Measurements of these correlations will be performed primarily using the PHENIX experiment at RHIC.  The specific goal of these analysis studies will be understanding the newly discovered enhancement of a certain type of particle produced by the above mentioned quarks because of the plasma, at both RHIC with PHENIX and also at the ATLAS experiment at the LHC.   For this reason our data analysis will include comparisons to, and some limited research activities using, the ATLAS experiment as well.  In addition to these analysis projects, the investigator's group at Ohio University will support the upgrade of computing, analysis, hardware of PHENIX through operation of the PHENIX Sub-Detector called the Lead-Glass Calorimeter Detector as well as through leadership of groups and projects of detector development and analysis.  

The project results in a number of broad benefits to society beyond the important goal of educating and training students.  The PI maintains organizations in the state of Ohio and beyond to exchange Heavy Ion knowledge.  International collaboration among nuclear physicists around the world is strengthened.  Furthermore, the project contributes to the development of future computing in the nation.  Finally the investigator contributes to the improvement of physics teaching related to the above research at Ohio University and in the Appalacian region by developing "Active Learning" classroom techniques.

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in major advances for relativistic heavy ion (RHI) collision studies in measurement precision for the PHENIX experiment of the production rates of very high-energy pairs of high energy versions of X-rays, called direct photons, and hadrons which are particles like protons that are made up of quarks that interact with the strong nuclear force.  These measured production rates have revealed new information about the Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP), a new kind of nuclear matter discovered at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) a little over 10 years ago which has incredible properties due to its strongly interacting nature.  This was done by studying correlations between the photons and hadrons and developing new techniques that employ particle ?isolation? which require particles be produced without any other particles nearby.  This helps cleanly identify and differentiate the photons from backgrounds. Measurements of these correlations were made primarily using the PHENIX experiment at RHIC.   The data analysis included comparisons to, and some research using, the ATLAS experiment, at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) as well, to make similar photon-hadron measurements.  The measurements showed what happens when high energy particles lose energy in the QGP and where that energy shows up.  This was elucidated by the project for two cases, the first case being when large heavy ions collide, and the second case, possibly for the first time, when smaller ions collide, which may also mean that the smaller ions also are capable of creating a QGP.  In addition to these analysis projects, the investigator's group at Ohio University successfully supported the upgrade of computing, analysis, and hardware of PHENIX through operation of the PHENIX Sub-Detector called the Lead-Glass Calorimeter Detector until PHENIX data-taking completed in 2016.  As well, through leadership of groups and projects of detector development and analysis, the PI?s group supported PHENIX and also a new version of PHENIX called sPHENIX which started construction in 2018.  Educational outcomes of the project included 3 completed Ph. D.?s and associated dissertations, 2 Master?s Theses, and one undergraduate honors thesis all at Ohio University.   Significant Broader Impacts by the project were accomplished by the PI's maintaining a midwest-region network of RHI scientists through organization of a conference in 2014 which continued from another previously organized in 2010 and also participation in improvements in physics teaching through participation in the meetings and committees of the local chapter of the American Association of Physics Teachers.  Even larger broader impacts than these were made by the project's PI through a three year role serving  as the Chair of the RHIC/AGS Users Executive Committee, which respresents about 2000 scientists at RHIC, interfacing to Brookhaven National Lab management and building various human infrastructures important for successful research at RHIC.
